Excellent (4): Clearly defines the problem, objectives, and significance of the project.
Good (3): Well-defined problem but lacks full clarity on significance.
Fair (2): Problem statement is vague or lacks clarity.
Poor (1): Problem is poorly defined or irrelevant.

Excellent (4): Comprehensive and well-thought-out approach; method is appropriate and feasible. Show strong contributions
Good (3): Solid approach, but lacks depth in some areas. Limited contributions.
Fair (2): Approach is basic, lacks detail or feasibility.

Excellent (4): Data sources are relevant, reliable, and well-documented; clear quality assessment.
Good (3): Adequate data sources but some concerns about quality or relevance.
Fair (2): Data sources are unclear or not well-documented.
Poor (1): No clear data sources, poor quality data.

Excellent (4): Methodology is clearly described, justified, and aligns with project objectives. Clear EDA process.
Good (3): Methodology is good but lacks some justification or details.
Fair (2): Basic methodology, unclear justification for choices.

Excellent (4): Well-justified timeline and resources, clear risk assessment.
Good (3): Feasible project, though some risks not addressed.
Fair (2): Feasibility unclear, some risks or resources not considered.

Excellent (4): Strong potential for significant impact on business/industry.
Good (3): Good potential for impact, but could be more clearly articulated.

Excellent (4): Engaging, clear, and confident delivery with smooth transitions.
Good (3): Good presentation, minor issues with delivery.
Poor (1): Poor presentation, hard to follow or disorganized.

Excellent (4): Visuals/slides are clear, well-organized, and support key points.
Good (3): Slides are clear, but some visuals could be improved.
Poor (1): Poor or no use of visuals to support the presentation.

Excellent (4): Insightful, thoughtful responses to all questions.
Good (3): Good responses, but lacks depth on some points.
Fair (2): Struggles to answer some questions effectively.

Excellent (4): All members contributed equally and were well-coordinated.
Good (3): Most members contributed, some coordination issues.
Poor (1): Poor collaboration, dominated by one member.
